Conversion of biomass platform compounds to γ-Valerolactone (GVL) is of significant for biomass high-value utilization. In this study, a range of innovative zirconium-based catalysts (Zr-5ASA-X) were synthesized utilizing 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) as the ligand through a formic acid (FA) modification strategy. Zr-5ASA (2:1)-300 exhibited excellent catalytic activity for transfer hydrogenation of bio-derived ethyl levulinate (EL) to GVL with a high EL conversion of 98.8 % and GVL selectivity of 98.6 % in isopropanol under moderate reaction conditions (170 ℃ and 5 h). The characterization results revealed that H + dissociated from FA combined with the electron donating group -NH2 to generate electron-withdrawing effects, further boosting the intensity of Zr4+ Lewis acid active sites. More importantly, the catalyst can repetitively use at least five runs without an obvious loss of activity. Finally, a kinetic model describing this reaction was established and the possible reaction mechanism was proposed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Ethyl levulinate γ-Valerolactone Catalytic transfer hydrogenation Zirconium-based catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass stands out as the primary renewable organic carbon resource abundantly available in nature. Conversion of biomass into high value-added platform compounds can not only decrease the consumption of fossil resources but also realize the high economic and sustainable synthesis of fine chemicals and bulk chemicals [1–3]. Among these platform compounds, γ-valerolactone (GVL) is one of the most anticipated multifunctional compounds with broad application prospects [4,5]. GVL has unique solvent characteristics to deconstruct biomass or solubilize lignin [6], which is key to a viable biorefinery. It can be further transformed into a variety of value-added downstream products, such as polyester precursor dimethyl adipate [7], food additive [8], etc. Besides, it can be used as fuel additives [4,5] or transformed into biofuel or fuel additives [9]. Efficiently conversion of bio-derived platform compounds such as levulinic acid (LA), furfural, and hydroxymethylfurfural, as well as via one-pot catalytic transformation of renewable sugars (cellulose, hemicellulose, and fructose) is of great significant for renewable energy development. Synthesis of GVL from levulinic acid or its esters with high GVL yield has attracted much attention [10–12]. In particularly, catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) using alcohols as H-donor offers an energy-saving route for LA or its esters to GVL [13,14]. In these research, zirconium-based catalysts exhibit good activity in the CTH reaction. Su et al. [15] prepared d-amino acid oxidase (DAAO) coordinated to Zn (II) and Zr (IV) in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) forming the (ZnHPO4) @ DAAO@(ZrHPO4) coordination network catalyst, and the conversion of LA is 99.8 % and the yield of GVL is 98.3 % at 130 ℃ within 2 h. Magnetic Fe3O4@Zr-FDCA hybrid with Lewis acid and Lewis base sites was reported [16] to obtain a GVL yield of 94.5 % at 180 °C for 5 h in CTH conversion of ethyl levulinate (EL) to GVL and displayed a good reusability. Liu et al. [17] designed a series of zirconium-lignocellulose hybrid catalysts assisted by organic acids. Formic acid-assisted Zr@PS-FA exhibited excellent catalytic activity for CTH of LA to GVL with a high yield of 95.6 %. The excellent activity of Zr@PS-FA due to the largest surface area and interaction effects between acids (Lewis acid and Brønsted acid) and Lewis base sites enhanced by organic acid. The acid/base properties of Zr@PS could be tuned by introduction of organic acids. Our team successfully prepared [18] a novel zirconium-coordinated catalyst Zr-SDBC-P by self-assembly method using biochar as a natural ligand with abundant organic functional groups (-COOH, Ar-OH). The Zr-SDBC-P showed satisfactory catalytic activity in conversion of EL into GVL and had good stability. As can be seen from the above references, Zr can be a good metal coordination center to construct a stable, efficient Zr-based catalyst for the CTH of LA or its esters to GVL. From the perspective of green catalysis, inexpensive, non-toxic, and stable ligands should be the preferred choice. Salicylic acid and its derivatives are good, non-toxic, and stable ligands due to their structure of hydroxyl and carboxyl groups and good biocompatibility. 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA), known as the mesalazine, is widely used in medicine, but rarely used as a catalyst ligand. Because the existence of an electron-donating group amino group will reduce electron cloud density of the metal center through conjugation effect, which is not beneficial to the coordination with metal ions. However, with the acid assisted, the combination of amino group and H + will change the electronic effect of the group in the benzene ring and be beneficial for coordination. More important, acid property of the designed catalyst can be tuned flexibly, which plays a key role in catalytic performance. In this study, a novel Zr-based catalyst was synthesized through modification with formic acid (FA). Unlike traditional methods for enhancing catalytic properties, this approach primarily focuses on FA modification to induce electronic effects on the catalyst surface and further strengthen Zr4+ Lewis acid sites. Throughout the experiments, the effects of FA amounts, catalyst dosage, reaction temperature and time in EL transfer hydrogenation reaction were explored. Our findings demonstrate that modification of the catalyst with a small amount of acid significantly enhances catalytic performance under identical reaction conditions, offering a new idea for design of metal-coordinated catalyst. 2 Experiment 2.1 Materials Hydrochloric acid was bought from Hunan Huihong Reagent Co., Ltd. Ethyl levulinate (EL,99 %), ZrCl4, n-dodecane (99 %) and 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) all from Shanghai Maclin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Nitric acid (68 %), sulfuric acid (98 %), 2-propanol (98 %), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF)(AR), formic acid (88 %), sodium bicarbonate (AR), potassium hydrogen phthalate (AR), phenolphthalein (AR), methyl orange (AR) and sodium hydroxide (AR) all from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalysts preparation For preparation of Zr-5ASA-X [17,19,20], 0.4697 g (2 mmol) ZrCl4 and 0.6131 g (4 mmol) 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) were dissolved in 20 mL and 10 mL DMF, respectively. ZrCl4 and 5-ASA solutions were sonicated for 15 min, then ZrCl4 solution was gently added to 5-ASA solution, and the mixture was subsequently sonicated for 15 min. 140 μL formic acid (FA) was added slowly to adjust the pH value to 1.39. The mixture was placed in a 100 mL teflon lining and heated at 160 ℃ for 24 h. The precipitate was filtered, and rinsed with water until the filtrate was neutral. This sample was dried in a vacuum drying oven at 60 ℃ for 12 h and recorded as Zr-5ASA-140. The number 140 means the usage amount of FA. For comparison, Zr-5ASA, Zr-5ASA-400, Zr-5ASA-HCl and Zr-5ASA (2:1)-300 were prepared. These catalysts were prepared without FA, 400 uL FA added, using 300 uL HCl to adjust the pH value to 1.39, and molar ratio of ZrCl4:5-ASA is 2:1. 2.3 Catalysts characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were tested on a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer with a Cu target Kα radiation, scanned from 5 to 90° in 2θ at a scanning speed of 10 °/min operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 surface area analyzer at 77 K. The samples were degassed at 120 °C for at least 12 h prior to the measurement. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were collected in transmission mode at room temperature with a resolution of 4 cm−1, using 20 scans per spectrum in the region of 400 - 4000 cm−1 on a NEXUS spectrometer. The samples were prepared by the KBr pellet method. Mass ratio of the sample and KBr was 1:100. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted on a Thermo Fisher specrometer using a non-monochromatized Al Kɑ as the excitation source (hυ =1486.6 eV) at 12 kV and 6 mA. And C1s orbital (284.8 eV) was used to correct the binding energy. 13C Solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (13C NMR) spectroscopy were performed using a Bruker AVANCE Ⅲ HD 400 MHZ solid state NMR spectrometer at frequency of 100.625 MHz (13C). Samples were packed in conventional 4.0 mm ZrO2 rotors and rotated at MAS rates of 10 kHz. Spectra were acquired using CP with a contact pulse 6.5 us. The spectrum width was 30 kHz and the cycle delay was 1–2 s. The contents of Zr in Zr-based catalysts were determined by ICP-OES (Thermo Fisher's ICAP 7200 devices). The samples were processed by microwave digestion. The content was calculated by using a standard curve based on known concentration of zirconium in concentrated HNO3 (68 %, w/w). Before analysis, 0.12 g catalyst was pretreated with 10 mL concentrated HNO3 (68 %, w/w) at 160 °C for 3 h. The content of C, H was obtained from elemental analysis by using the VARIO EL Ⅲ analyzer, and N was detected on TEA-6000 NS detector both by oxidative combustion method. Pyridine-adsorbed FT-IR (Py-FTIR) was performed using a Bruker Tensor 27 apparatus. In the experiment, the catalyst pellet was fixed in the infrared cell and purified at 100 ℃for 1 hour under vacuum condition (1 × 10−3 Pa), then cooled to room temperature and scanned for background. The probe molecule pyridine was pulsed into the cell for 45 min until the acid sites were saturated with pyridine. After that, physically adsorbed pyridine was removed under vacuum condition (1 × 10−3 Pa) at 140 ℃ (or 170 ℃, 200 ℃) for 30 min. The infrared spectra in the range of 1700–1400 cm−1 were recorded after cooling to room temperature. Thermogravimetry curves of the samples were recorded by German Netsch STA 409 PC thermogravimetric analyzer and the temperature increased to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in N2 atmosphere. Determination of surface acidity of the catalysts by Boehm titration [21] was carried out by preparing a solution of 0.1 N NaOH, NaHCO3 and HCl solution. Each of the solution was standardized with the primary standardized solution. After standardization, 0.05 g (m1) of the sample was immersed in 20 mL of 0.1 N NaOH or NaHCO3 for 24 h, respectively. Then each suspension was titrated with 0.1 N HCl. And each sample titrated three times in parallel. The amount of acidic carboxyl, and phenol groups can be calculated using the following equations. (1) η Carboxyl ( mmol/g ) = 20 × C NaHC O 3 − V HCl × C HCl m 1 (2) η Phenol ( mmol / g ) = 20 × C NaOH − V HCl × C HCl m 1 − η Carboxyl 2.4 Catalytic activity tests The reaction was carried out in a 50 mL cylindrical stainless-steel reactor. Typically, the reactor contained 1 mmol EL, 10 mL IPA as a hydrogen donor and solvent, 0.2 mmol n-dodecane as a standard and 0.1 g catalyst. The mixture was purged three times with N2 before the reaction, and was heated to the specified temperature with stirring at 450 rpm and maintained for the desired reaction time. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled, and the liquid products were analyzed by GC and GC–MS. 2.5 Products analysis GC–MS (Shimadzu GCMS-QP2030) was used to confirmed GVL and the intermediate of isopropyl levulinic acid (IPL) about transesterification of EL and IPA with a HP-INNOWAX capillary column (30.0 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 mm), and the quality analysis is carried out by Shimadzu gas-chromatograph (GC 2030) with chromatographic column SH-1701 (30.0 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 mm). The following temperature program was used in the analysis: 90 °C (keeping for 4 min) then increased at a rate of 10 °C/min to 100 °C (held for 5 min), and 100 °C increased at a rate of 20 °C/min to 120 °C (held for 2 min), lastly 120 °C increased at a rate of 80 °C/min to 190 °C (held for 2 min). n-Dodecane was used as an internal standard in the GC analysis. Typically, the EL conversion (CEL), GVL selectivity (SGVL) and IPL selectivity (SIPL) were calculated using the following equations: (3) E L c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( 1 − M o l e o f E L I n i t i a l m o l e o f E L ) × 100 % (4) G V L s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = ( M o l e o f G V L I n i t i a l m o l e o f E L − M o l e o f E L ) × 100 % (5) I P L s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = ( M o l e o f I P L I n i t i a l m o l e o f E L − M o l e o f E L ) × 100 % 2.6 Recycling tests To examine the recyclability of Zr-5ASA (2:1)-300, the catalyst was recovered from the reaction mixture by filtration and washed with 2-propanol for six times. After being dried for 12 h at 60 °C in a vacuum oven, the recovered catalyst was directly used for the next run under the same reaction conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts XRD patterns of Zr-5ASA, Zr-5ASA-140, Zr-5ASA-400 and Zr-5ASA (2:1)-300 were shown in Fig. 1 . All catalysts exhibited large and wide peaks without obvious crystallinity, indicating the irregular connectivity between Zr and 5ASA.The porous structures and surface areas of these catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption desorption analysis. The results showed that the catalysts have no pore structure and very small surface areas, about 1–3 cm2/g (Table S2). To explore the coordination of zirconium species with 5-ASA, FT-IR analysis was performed. As seem in Fig. 2 , the peak at around 620cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of Zr-O, indicated successful coordination of Zr4+ with 5-ASA. In addition, the most prominent peaks around 1400 cm−1 and 1500 to 1700 cm−1 both appear in the four samples, which attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration of the -CO2-. Distances between these two peaks can reveal information about the coordination mode of -COOH in 5-ASA with zirconium [22–24]. When the 5-ASA molecule acts as a monodentate ligand, it shows a splitting of more than 200 cm−1. And a bidentate ligand, it falls within the range of 50–150 cm−1. Bridging ligands are typically expected to exhibit splitting in the range of 130–200 cm−1. The peak distances of the -CO2-of symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration, the catalysts Zr-5ASA, Zr-5ASA-140, and Zr-5ASA-400 ranged from 159 to 163 cm−1, implying that 5-ASA coordinated with Zr in the form of a bridge. However, the addition of FA didn't change the coordination mode. For the catalyst Zr-5ASA (2:1)-300, it was 150 cm−1, suggesting that 5-ASA was coordinated with Zr in a chelated form. The broad peak at 2500 cm−1 of 5-ASA is attributed to NH and OH stretching vibration [25–28] but in the spectra of catalysts, the broad peak shifted to around 3200 cm−1, which corresponds to the peak of secondary amine salt (Ar-NH3 +) of N-H [29], indicating that Ar-OH also coordinate with Zr4+. 13C solid-state NMR spectra of Zr-5ASA and Zr-5ASA-140 were shown in Fig. 3 . All resonances founded between 100 and 160 ppm indicated the aromatic nature of the catalysts and the presence of the metal center. However, the spectral broadening makes it difficult to determine the number of ligands that are present in the catalysts [30]. The peak at chemical shifts of 162 and 173 ppm can be associated to hydroxyl connected carbon on benzene ring and carboxyl carbon. Elemental analysis of the catalysts was performed, the results as well as the ICP results on Zr content were presented in Table 1 . If Zr4+ is coordinated with the carboxyl group of 5-ASA in a equal mole ratio, the atomic ratio of carbon to zirconium of the catalyst is 7:1, like the Zr-5ASA-140. Then, it can be inferred that the carboxyl of Zr-5ASA catalysts may coordinated to Zr4+ in a mixed way of chelated (M-OOCR) and bridge form ((MO)2CR). The atomic ratio of carbon to zirconium of acid-modificated catalysts Zr-5ASA-400 and Zr-5ASA(2:1)−300 were smaller than 7:1, it inferred that 5-ASA may be as a bridging bidentate ((MO)2CR). And there may be a monatomic bridging ligand with additional bridging(MM-OCR-O-M) in the Zr-5ASA-400. Besides, the number ratio of H and N atoms in the catalysts (Zr-5ASA-140 and Zr-5ASA-400) increased with the addition of FA, indicated that FA was absorbed by the amino groups, which affected the acidity and catalytic activity of the catalyst. Py-FTIR was used to detect the relative content of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid in the samples, and the spectra obtained at 140 °C were used for analysis. As seen in Fig. S3, the peaks of 1456 and 1616 cm−1 were attributed to pyridine absorbed on Lewis acid sites, which included Zr-O-C and coordinatively unsaturated Zr4+. The peaks at 1450 and 1640 cm−1 were assigned to the interaction of pyridine with Brønsted acid, which involved some of the hydroxyl and carboxyl groups on the ligand that aren't involved in coordination. The bond of 1490cm−1 was ascribed to both of these two acid sites [31,32]. The amount of Lewis and Brønsted acids of the catalysts were shown in Table 2 . With the modification of FA, the density of both Brønsted acid and Lewis acid of the catalysts increased, suggested that the addition of FA in the catalyst preparation was beneficial to the anchoring of Zr4+ , which was consistent with the results of elemental analysis and ICP analysis (Table 1). The content of -COOH and Ar-OH on catalysts were evaluated by Boehm titration, and the results were also shown in Table 2. The density of Brønsted acid was also positively correlated with FA amount, indicated that FA may facilitate Zr4+ anchoring, which was consistent with the results of py-FTIR spectra. The amount of -OH was larger than that of -COOH in the catalysts indicated that it is the carboxyl groups that mainly coordinate with Zr4+in ligands, which was proved by FT-IR analysis. Thermal stability of 5-ASA, Zr-5ASA, Zr-5ASA-140, Zr-5ASA-400 Zr-5ASA (2:1)-300 were determined by TGA and DTG. Fig. 4 a showed that all the catalysts exhibit better thermal stability compared with the ligand 5-ASA (Fig. S4). Fig. 4b showed that the first decomposition temperature was 105 − 118 °C, which was owing to removal of water adsorbed on the catalyst surface. The decomposition peak of the catalysts between 351 °C and 407 °C came from the decomposition of organic functional groups coordinated with zirconium and −NH2. The peaks of Zr-5ASA (2:1)-300 (207 °C), Zr-5ASA-400 (236 °C), and Zr-5ASA-140 (270 °C) were derived from the decomposition of FA. 3.2 Influence of FA amount on catalytic activities of the catalysts Influence of FA amount on the catalytic performance of these catalysts was shown in Fig. 5 . Compared the catalytic activities of Zr-5ASA to Zr-5ASA-140, conversion of EL increased from 65.4 % to 83.6 %, and yield of GVL increased from 84.3 % to 90.2 %. As FA amount increased from 140 uL to 300 uL, activities of the catalyst strengthened. As can be seen in Table 1, content of Zr active centers increased with FA addition increasing, which led to improved catalytic activities. HCl instead of FA was used to adjust pH value. The catalyst Zr-5ASA-HCl was prepared by adjusting pH to the same pH 1.39 with HCl. The catalytic activity of Zr-5ASA-HCl was poorer than that of the FA-modified catalysts and better than that of Zr-5ASA. It is suggested that -NH2 in the complex with H + to form -N +H3. The withdrawing electron effect affected the strength of active centers Zr4+ through the conjugated system of benzene. To verify this hypothesis, XPS analysis of Zr-5ASA, Zr-5ASA-140, and Zr-5ASA-HCl were performed, and results were shown in Fig. 6. Four peaks could be observed in the C1s spectra (Fig. 6 a), which were attributed to C–C/C–H (284.8 eV), C-N (285.4 eV), C–O (286.7 eV) and O–C = O (288.6 eV). The O1s spectra (Fig. 6b) obtained two peaks, which were assigned to C=O (531.56 eV) and C–O (533.23 eV) [33]. In addition, in the N1s spectra (Fig. 6c), the peak belonging to the -NH2 was at 404.2 eV in Zr-5ASA and at 401.5 eV in Zr-5ASA-140 and Zr-5ASA-HCl. In the acidic condition, the chemical environment change was probably caused by -NH2 with H + to form -N +H3 [34–37]. The results were consistent with the speculation and FT-IR results. Fig. 6d showed that the binding energy of Zr 3d3/2 in Zr-5ASA-140 and Zr-5ASA-HCl slightly increased from 183.4 eV to 183.9 and 184.1 eV, respectively, compared with Zr-5ASA. The higher positive charge of the zirconium species in Zr-5ASA-140 and Zr-5ASA-HCl means that the Lewis acidity of the zirconium center in Zr-5ASA-140 and Zr-5ASA-HCl had be enhanced. Thus, the increase of Zr4+ binding energy could verify the existence of the electron-withdrawing effect, further confirming that it originated from the formation of electron withdrawing group -N +H3 In summary, the catalytic performance enhancement was due to electronic effects and Zr4+ acid sites amount increase. Effect of molar ratio of ZrCl4/5-ASA were also demonstrated in Fig. 6. When the molar ratio of ZrCl4/5-ASA was changed from 1:2 to 2:1, the conversion of EL and the selectivity to GVL was greatly improved. 3.3 Influence of reaction parameters Influence of catalyst dosage on the EL CTH reaction was investigated. As shown in Fig. 7 a, EL conversion increased from 6.1 % to 98.8 % and GVL selectivity increased from 75.3 % to 98.6 % when the dose was increased from 50 mg to 100 mg. It was shown that more Lewis acid-base sites were needed to promote the reaction to catalyze conversion of EL to GVL, therefore, 100 mg was selected as the optimal dose in the subsequent experiments. Reaction time is another important factor in catalytic reaction. Reaction time was investigated from 2 h to 6 h, and the results were shown in Fig. 7b. With prolonging reaction time, EL conversion and GVL selectivity increased, whereas IPL selectivity decreased. The maximum EL conversion and GVL selectivity were 98.8 % and 98.6- %, respectively, when reaction time was 5 h. So 5 h was the optimal reaction time in the experiment. Effect of reaction temperature was studied range from 140 °C to 180 °C. As shown in Fig. 7c, at 140 °C, EL conversion was 21.6 % and GVL selectivity was 60.2 %. With an increasing reaction temperature, both EL conversion and GVL selectivity were increased, and the intermediate isopropyl levulinate (IPL) selectivity was reduced. When the temperature was 170 °C, the conversion of EL and selectivity of GVL were significantly increased to 98.8 % and 98.6 %, which inferred that the reaction temperature has a significant impact on catalytic performance. High temperature was required to provide energy, cross energy barriers, and promote reaction progress. When further increased the temperature, EL conversion and GVL selectivity were almost unchang. Therefore 170 °C was the best reaction temperature. 3.4 Recyclability experiment Recyclability experiment of Zr-5ASA (2:1)-300 was carried out under the optimal reaction condition to evaluate the stability and reuse performance of the catalyst. As can be seen from Fig. 8 , there was no obvious loss of catalytic activity after five repeated cycles. FT-IR spectrum of the used catalyst (Fig. S5) was totally the same as that of the fresh one, which indicated the active functional groups of Zr-5ASA (2:1)-300 maintained well. Thus, the catalyst Zr-5ASA (2:1)-300 has good stability. 3.5 Kinetic study Based on previous research and experimental data, there are two pathways for hydrogenation from EL to GVL. One pathway in the presence of isopropanol (IPA) is EL transesterification with IPA to form IPL and lactones into GVL. Another route is the hydrogenation and internal esterification of EL to GVL in IPA. The research routes are shown in Scheme 1 . Previously, when investigating the reaction temperature (Fig. 7c), it was found that the temperature change had a great influence on the selectivity of GVL. The selectivity of GVL increased with the increase in reaction temperature. Under 170℃ for 5 h, the GVL selectivity was 98.6 %. Therefore, the reaction temperatures of 140, 150 and 160 ℃ were selected for kinetic study. Since IPA is excessive in the reaction, taking the amount of IPA as a constant. the reaction will be studied according to the first-order reaction kinetic model. The differential equations are as follows: d [ E L ] d t = − k 1 [ E L ] − k 3 [ E L ] d [ I P L ] d t = k 1 [ E L ] − k 2 [ I P L ] d [ G V L ] d t = k 2 [ I P L ] + k 3 [ E L ] Where [] is the molar concentration of each component, and ki is the apparent rate constant at constant temperature. The fitting degree is measured by calculating the experimental concentration of reactants and products and the residual of the calculated concentration. The smaller the value of fobj, the better the fitting degree. Where C m, n, Calc and C m, n, exp respectively represent the calculated and experimental concentrations of component m (EL, IPL and GVL) at reaction time n: F o b j = ∑ m { ∑ n = 1 n p [ C m , n , c a l c − C m , n , e x p ] 2 } Reaction conditions: 1 mmol EL, 100 mg catalyst, 10 mL IPA It can be seen from Table 3 that the reaction rate k3 (EL → GVL) was greater than k2 (IPL → GVL) was greater than k1 (EL → IPL) at 140 and 150 ℃, and showed that the reaction was mainly from the direct hydrogenation of EL to GVL in IPA. At 160 ℃, the reaction rate k3 (EL → GVL) was greater than k1 (EL → IPL) and greater than k2 (IPL → GVL), which could also be confirmed. Compared with k3 (0.04278 and 0.06676) at 140 ℃ and 150 ℃, k3 (0.55809) at 160 ℃ was much larger, inferred that there is a reaction energy barrier between 150 ℃ and 160 ℃ for the EL hydrogenation to GVL, and higher temperature is required to provide reaction energy, which further indicated that the activation energy of transformation of EL to GVL is high. The results also showed that there are more Lewis acid sites and fewer Bronsted acid sites in the catalyst, which was also consistent with the results of ICP and Boehm titration. The Fobj value in Table 3 represents the degree of fitting between the kinetic model and the experimental data, a smaller value indicates a better fit of its kinetic model to the experimental data. At reaction temperatures of 140, 150, and 160, the Fobj values were 2.60×10−5, 2.38×10−5 and 3.40×10−4, respectively, which were much less than 1, inferred that the first-stage kinetic model can fit the actual data well. Fig. 9 is a fitting plot of the actual and theoretical concentrations of the substrate EL, intermediate IPL and product GVL over time at different reaction temperatures. At 140 ℃ and 150 ℃, the theoretical concentrations of EL, IPL, and GVL were well fitted to the experimental concentrations. When the temperature increases to 160 ℃, it can be seen that the theoretical concentration doesn't fit the experimental concentration as well as the low temperature, it is inferred that when the temperature reaches 160 ℃, the energy barrier of the reaction is crossed and the reaction proceeds rapidly with a rapid increase in the k-value, which leads to a first-order kinetic model that doesn't fit the experimental data as well, so for a reaction at different temperatures it cannot be fitted with a single kinetic model. The fit of EL conversion rates related to the theoretical and experimental values can be analyzed through the parity plots of Fig. 10 . As shown in Fig. 10, R2 is 0.9848, indicated that the kinetic model can be in good agreement with the experimental value. 3.6 Possible reaction mechanism Through the experimental data, kinetic studies and relevant literatures, the possible reaction mechanism of the hydrogenation of EL to GVL in the presence of the catalyst Zr-5ASA (2:1) – 300 was speculated (Scheme 2 ). The above results and discussion could confirm that Zr4+ successfully coordinated with 5-ASA to form abundant Lewis acid-base sites (-Zr4+-O2−-), which is necessary for the hydrogenation of EL to GVL [38]. Firstly, the unsaturated acid-base sites - Zr4+-O2−- absorb IPA to form alcohol and H + [39]. Then, the electron-rich carbonyl oxygen in EL interacts with electron-deficient Zr4+. When the Lewis acid site interacts with EL, a six-membered ring transition state is formed, which completes the transfer hydrogenation process to transform 4-HPE with acetone released [40]. Lastly, the H + released from IPA combined with the carbonyl group in 4-HPE to form carbonyl positive ions, further undergo intramolecular esterification to form GVL and remove ethanol at the same time [41]. 4 Conclusion In this study, a series of Zr-5ASA-X catalysts were prepared by FA modification. Catalytic transfer hydrogenation of EL to GVL in IPA was chosen to detect the catalytic activity of the catalysts. Zr-5ASA (2:1)−300 has superior activity and the 98.8 % EL conversion and the 98.6 % GVL selectivity has been achieved. The characterizations revealed the relationship between catalytic property improvement and FA addition. FA modified catalyst to formed an electron-withdrawing effect and further enhanced Zr4+ acid site strength. In addition, the addition of acid could raise the Zr4+ anchoring. The synergy of the two factors together promoted the improvement of catalytic performance. In summary, this method provided inspiration and ideas for strengthening catalytic performance and exploring the role of acids in coordination. coredata.dc:description: Conversion of biomass platform compounds to γ-Valerolactone (GVL) is of significant for biomass high-value utilization. In this study, a range of innovative zirconium-based catalysts (Zr-5ASA-X) were synthesized utilizing 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) as the ligand through a formic acid (FA) modification strategy. Zr-5ASA (2:1)-300 exhibited excellent catalytic activity for transfer hydrogenation of bio-derived ethyl levulinate (EL) to GVL with a high EL conversion of 98.8 % and GVL selectivity of 98.6 % in isopropanol under moderate reaction conditions (170 ℃ and 5 h). The characterization results revealed that H + dissociated from FA combined with the electron donating group -NH2 to generate electron-withdrawing effects, further boosting the intensity of Zr4+ Lewis acid active sites. More importantly, the catalyst can repetitively use at least five runs without an obvious loss of activity. Finally, a kinetic model describing this reaction was established and the possible reaction mechanism was proposed.
